documents.title: we 're wrapping up !
text: thanks everyone for your questions and to karen for her great answers .
we hope you enjoyed this !
have a lovely rest of the day and stay tuned for our coming final booker webchat with neel mukherjee , and for our coverage of the 2014 man booker prize announcement tomorrow .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 2:01pm thanks very much everyone , for your lovely comments and questions .
i 'm off now to podcast something or other .
i can not tell you how much i appreciate you all reading my book and showing up here to tell me so .
think of me , all dressed up tomorrow night , teetering about in heels significantly higher than i 've ever worn before .
i will win or break my neck trying !

omydays asks : i read your book over the summer and loved it , but what was totally extraordinary for me was when my father was bedridden and close to death two summers ago , he was hallucinating and in his mind he was walking with me in the atlas mountains where we had often walked with him as children .

as he lay in bed , he plucked weakly at his blanket and asked me to carry his backpack as it was too heavy and so i too plucked at the blanket and said i would , and he said walk on ahead ' as he would be going his own pace ' and i like , rosemary , i was happy to be asked to carry his load and he seemed at peace and in fact he died soon after .
i never imagined i would read something so close to my own experience .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:59pm but this is amazing !
i wrote that scene directly about my own father 's death , so all those details came from him and my last moments with him .
i can not believe we were both asked to carry those celestial backpacks !
i miss him so much i sometimes think i 've never put that backpack down again .
charlotte jones asks : thanks for your earlier answer .
i have another question too if there 's still time !
how important is spoken language to you in your writing ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:57pm do you mean dialogue ?
or do you mean the sound and rhythm of the prose ?
i do read all my work aloud as i 'm working - this has made it a little hard to adjust to my husband 's retirement .
i can shout the shouty parts if i 'm alone in the house , but of course i feel a fool if someone is there to hear me .
nowadays , i only mutter the shouty bits and often feel quite cross about it .

documents.title: `` as i 've aged , my obsession has become siblings ''
text: actualgraunreader asks : in both we are all completely beside ourselves and wits end there 's a lot about the problems of being the leftover from an experimental family .
i note that in the jane austen book club only grigg is really happy with how his parents ( well , his dad ) left him .
is this a subject you find yourself drawn to ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:54pm the subject of experimental families or of parental abandonment ?
i suppose i 'm very drawn to both .
as i 've aged though , my obsession has become siblings .
such a peculiar relationship in our lives - these people who were there while we grew up and know us all too well .
to transition that relationship from childhood to adulthood , what that means , how that happens or does n't happen - that 's where my brain seems to be at present .
c1airea asks : the booker prize has huge importance for us in the uk , but i wonder what significance it has to americans ( if any , granted that you 've only just become eligible ) .
what does it mean to you to be shortlisted ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:51pm i have been thrilled with the level of attention this has gotten in the states .

`perhaps some of this is because the door has just opened for americans , but i do also think there is an enormous level of respect for this particular prize and even without americans competing , we watch it pretty closely .
i know i do !
wadda asks : dear karen , i very much enjoyed reading your book and i found it both moving and thought provoking .
i recently read an interview with you regarding your thoughts on the animal rights movement where you said that you tried to avoid giving reductive answers to what are complex issues .
although i agree , to some extent , i would be interested if you could expand upon this a little .

i think it is clear from your book that you consider both rose and fern to have intrinsic value and interests , and i 'm not sure on what basis we should therefore not extend this to other sentient animals that likewise feel pain and experience emotions ( cows , pigs , sheep , fish ) .
if this step is taken then i find it difficult to justify most , if not all , animal experimentation and certainly the use of animals for food or fur where there are easily available alternatives .

i 'd be very interested to hear what you think are the complexities surrounding these issues and what your views are on why/whether you feel it is justifiable to eat meat and perform some experiments upon animals .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:49pm the only place where i see complexity is in medical research .
i see no justification at all for anything else , and even in the medical i would have to be persuaded this was the only way to get to something beneficial .
i completely agree with you - the more we learn about animal cognition and capability , the more we see how we 've underestimated our fellow creatures .
it is not just a matter of their welfare - it reflects on us when we do n't manage the empathy and sympathy suffering should evoke .
my father would say that we are animals , too - that we are designed to eat meat and that we would not ask cats to be vegetarians , so we should n't ask it of ourselves .
he would not approve of the horror of factory farming , but he would not become a vegetarian .
i myself have grown unhappy about eating meat .
first i tried to be careful as to where it came from - to believe that some standard of decency was involved in raising the animal , but lately i 've been trying to give it up entirely .
id8596092 asks : i loved your book , thank you .
it strikes me that a lot of your novel is about how much we can ever know the minds of not only animals but also the people around us our family and friends .
do you think we can we be better at understanding others with effort and practice , in the same way that the family and researchers tried to understand fern ?
or do you think understanding of others is an innate thing that either happens or does n't ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:38pm what a good question .
i assume that we are all limited by our own brains and experiences and can only understand other people and other creatures through a kind of translation that brings them closer to us .
this translation will always distort to some extent , and i suspect the less like us the creature is , the more distortion that translation will involve .
but i think it 's crucial that we continue to try - in fact i think the primary project of literature is to keep us trying .
patrice sarath asks : hi karen : i re-read we are all completely beside ourselves quite often .
the story becomes richer each time , because i re-read having the knowledge of the reveal .
did you start out writing the book knowing that it would be structured that way , or did it just organically flow from the story you were telling ?
that is , rosemary would naturally think of her family that way , so she would n't think of telling the reader right off the bat .
thanks .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:35pm i am thrilled to hear it holds up under rereading .
yes , i always the book with the structure it has .
i never it any other way .
it seems to me psychologically true to rosemary that she would ease up on that information rather than say it outright , as well as useful for my purposes in telling the story .
deborah green asks : wonderful , distressing , fabulously well-written book .
my question : why did the university have a say in what happened with fern ?

i understand it would have been difficult for the cookes to find somewhere that would take her , and from what lowell tells rose , it might have gone badly if fern had gone to a rescue place , but if the cookes are effectively fern 's parents , why do n't they get to make the decision ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:33pm legally the university owned fern .

the cases currently underway in new york state arguing for personhood rights for the great apes would put an end to this , but in the current situation these animals are legally classified as 'things ' and 'property ' .
having spent a great deal of money on the project already , the university would probably try to recoup some of the losses by selling the chimp to the highest bidder .
none of the families who raised nim chimpsky had any legal rights concerning his welfare .
nor were their wishes taken into consideration .
i wish it were otherwise .
justinejordan asks : can i ask which books you read in the course of your research ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:29pm i did about 10 years of research , so it would take me the whole hour and more to answer this question .
but i started with the various books written about home-raised chimps , most of which are referenced in the novel .
these books describe the lives of vicky hayes , nim chimpsky , washoe , lucy temerlin and others .
i went on to read books about chimps in the wild , about animal rights and the animal rights movement , and animal cognition in general .
i took some classes .
it was all fascinating .
martabausells asks : hi karen , we are all completely beside ourselves appears a high concept book in that it 's about a particular issue arising from an era of animal research .
do you think it 's undermining for the novel to be described as such ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:26pm have you heard william gibson 's definition of high concept ?
it goes like this : `` she 's the pope ; he 's a chimp ; they are cops . ''
obviously there 's room here for embarrassment , but i would also argue that my two most successful novels to date are the two that are high concept books .
obviously i want to have it both ways .
gravityarc asks : everyone else here has already said how brilliant the book is ( hear hear !
) , so straight to my question : we see the story through rosemary 's eyes , yet she 's reluctant to reveal too much of herself ( both to the reader and to the people around her ) .
it seems an interesting challenge to have created yourself a narrator who 's against talking about herself ; how tricky a tightrope did you feel you were treading with rosemary 's coyness ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:23pm very tricky indeed .
it 's not just that rosemary does n't want to talk about herself .
she has worked for years not to remember the things that she is now revealing .

because of that , she sometimes gives you two or three versions of the same event as she works her own way towards what actually happened , and she puts off some of the more painful parts for as long as she can .
but i also saw her as someone finally compelled to speak .
she feels that both her brother and her sister need her to do so now .
florawillis asks : hi karen , you 've mentioned in interviews part of your research involved speaking to people who have been part of similar scientific experiments as rosemary 's family .
what was their reaction to you writing this book ?
and how much of we are all completely beside ourselves did their experiences inform ?

guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:21pm none of these conversations took place until after the book was published , though it would have been so useful to have had them beforehand .

i would describe their reactions as largely positive , though in at least one case it 's clear that the woman who contacted me does not plan to read the book , the subject matter being too painful for her to want to read it .
kateinkew asks : hi karen , thank you for a wonderful book .
i loved every single moment and must admit , i knew the twist ' before i began reading ( thanks to a reveal-all review ) .
that said , knowing the twist did not diminish my reading experience in the slightest .
i am very curious to know whether you intended/expected the twist ' to be revealed by reviewers ( and even the book-jacket graphic designers ! )
from the outset or whether you thought it would be a well-kept secret ?
once again , thank you for my favourite book of 2014 - memorable , thought-provoking , funny and sad .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:18pm as god is my witness , i honestly did n't think about the problem i was creating for marketing and reviewers .
the process of writing a book is so removed in my mind from the process of publishing it that i often forget for great stretches that i eventually hope to do the latter .
i read my books to writing workshops and friends and i 'm often focussed just on keeping them entertained .
i never think about marketing at all .
and thank you for loving my book .

documents.title: `` i 'm very interested in genre of all sorts but particularly sf ''
text: homirmunn asks : dear karen your novel reminds me on some ways of your story what i did n't see , for one obvious reason ( which i 'll keep quiet about in case there are people sensitive about plot reveals ) but also because while not sf , it seems to be based upon your knowledge of and love of a whole range of science fiction tropes , those of us who read sf will get this .
others wo n't , but it does n't hinder them it appreciating the book .
how important is this double-voicing ( which is also in sarah canary ) to you ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:15pm i 'm very interested in genre of all sorts but particularly sf .
i ca n't always claim that i write sf but i always imagine that i 'm writing for the sort of reader who likes it .
in my mind this reader is someone who does n't mind working to understand what 's going on in a book , and is willing to be confused for quite some time as long as it all comes clear eventually .
this is also the kind of reader i think i am .
so yes , the double-voicing is important to me .
charlotte jones asks : hi and congratulations on being one of the first american writers to be shortlisted and good luck for tomorrow !
who are the other american writers you would like to see on the booker list in future years ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:13pm can i just say all my close friends ?
ursula le guin , molly gloss , jane hamilton , gail tsukiyama are some writers i really admire .
two recent books i really loved are station eleven , by emily st john mandel , and all the light we can not see , by anthony doerr .
i will surely think of hundreds more the minute i post this .
patricksproull asks : hello .
you translate some of fern 's sign language for us - she refers to spiders and a chimp she does n't like as deadly crawling shit .
could you say a bit about your research into chimp signing ?
how far was it possible to get fern 's voice into the book ?

guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:09pm there are a lot of books written about the particular experiments in which chimpanzees were raised in human homes in order to study language acquisition .
amazingly , in the first experiments , they tried to get chimpanzees to actually speak orally - something the chimp skeleton does not allow for .
washoe was the first chimp taught to sign and interestingly when she was integrated into chimp populations she taught the other chimps to sign as well .
there is a lot of information about washoe in the library and on the web .
fern 's dislike of spiders is just the same as washoe 's - fern 's sign is also the same as hers was .
ciara o'hara asks : it 's not going to be possible for me to fully express in words not only how much i enjoyed this book but also how much i was moved by it , thank you so much for writing it !
i read it during the summer but had no idea what it was going to be about when i began it , had n't read any reviews and did n't read the blurb either , i it up completely by accident .
i was heading away for a weekend , realised i 'd forgotten the book i had been reading , and grabbed your book in a hurry on the way to the airport just because i liked the title .
i 'm so glad i did and also that i was unfamiliar with the story .
i cried several times on public transport while reading it , and even when i was n't reading it , my eyes would well up if i thought about it at all .
i still ca n't discuss it or think about it without getting emotional , it really stays with you .

i do n't have a question , sorry , i just wanted to tell you how much i loved your book ( definitely one of my all-time favourites ) and to congratulate you on writing something so beautiful , thought-provoking and powerful .
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:05pm thank you .
i 'm getting a little teary myself , reading your response .
ktwc asks : dear karen , i 've just finished your novel and was really drawn into it .
i 've already started re reading it , partly as i read whilst feeding a small baby and am not at full mental capacity , but partly to absorb & appreciate the layers more deeply .
can you say something about how you managed the multiple layers of plot and truth during the writing ?
did you have a system ?
have you used similar approaches in your other novels or did this one bring a new way of working ?
many congratulations on your nomination and all the best !
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:04pm i 'm impressed that you were able to read while feeding a small baby .
i could do nothing but watch television when my children were small .
a lot of the layers came about organically as part of an older narrator trying to remember events in her childhood .
i think that we organise and narrate our own memories in ways that create meaning and truth for us but are maybe not the most truthful memories - by which i mean accurate .
i think i do try in all my work to have multiple viewpoints and multiple layers of plot , but maybe more successfully in this book .
cyandell asks : thanks for your novel .
i read it on holiday , knowing nothing about it in advance .
i 'm glad that i did n't , because those early pages established rosemary 's relationship with fern without any adult labelling getting in the way .
did you have any qualms about when to reveal fern 's identity , or how to talk about it in public ?
guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:01pm hello , cyandell .
i always conceived of the novel with fern 's identity delayed and i honestly did n't think through how how this would constrain people talking about the book - readers and reviewers and marketers .

documents.title: karen is with us now
text: thanks for the questions that are already coming in .
karen has arrived to guardian towers : guardian contributor karenjoyfowlerwebcht 13 october 2014 1:00pm hello !
here i am and delighted to be so .
thank you all for the comments already posted .
i 'll be trying to answer them all .
karen joy fowler 's novel caused some head-scratching among reviewers when it was published earlier this year .
how does one write about a book that has a major plot reveal on the 77th page , and how much does it matter ?

now that it has reached booker shortlist stage , there can be few readers who do n't know the secret of the cooke family , whose household is left with a gaping hole by the disappearance of its most vivacious member , fern .
anyone as yet unfamiliar with the novel can catch up with it in liz jensen 's review .
those who would prefer not to know can consort with science blogger henry nicholls .
fowler is the wild card of this year 's booker and possibly of the whole publishing year with this historically-rooted tale of scientific inquiry trumping good sense .

it has already won the pen/faulkner award in the us , and garnered glowing write-ups , from the guardian 's description of it as an achingly funny , deeply serious heart-breaker [ and ] a moral comedy to shout about from the treetops , to the new york times 's praise as a novel so readably juicy and surreptitiously smart , it deserves all the attention it can get .
karen will be online on monday 13 october between 1 and 2pm bst , and will endeavour to answer all your questions .

bulletin.text: In the fifth of our Man Booker webchats, the author of We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves was online to answer your questions. From her obsession with sibling relationships to her research and thoughts on home-raised chimps, catch up with her answers here.
